issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

fields.customfield_12310192: Additionally, this patch updates maven-site-plugin to 3.6 and doxia-module-markdown to 1.8-SNAPSHOT to work around problems with unknown schemas in URLs in markdown formatted content.

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

fields.description: A lot of fixes went into Apache Yetus 0.4.0 wrt releasedocs and how it's output gets rendered with mvn site.  We should re-run releasedocs for all releases and refresh the content to use the new formatting.
fields.summary: refresh changelog/release notes with newer Apache Yetus build

comments.body: I'm going to raise this to a blocker since the -alpha1 notes get wonky.
I'm going to downgrade this in priority since it's not related specifically to the 3.0.0-alpha3 release.
I'd rather you not.  Right now we have a bunch of notes on the website that are unreadable.

-00:
* update with 0.5.0-SNAPSHOT
* Change parameters for releasedocmaker to not include the quotes
* update maven-site-plugin to 3.6, and doxia-1.8-SHAPSHOT so that the markdown renders correctly

This message was automatically generated.

Thanks for working on this Allen. A few review comments:

* Indentation looks wrong for pom.xml change
* Looks like some releases were deleted in this update:

{noformat}
-> % git st | grep deleted
	deleted:    hadoop-common-project/hadoop-common/src/site/markdown/release/0.13.1/CHANGES.0.13.1.md
	deleted:    hadoop-common-project/hadoop-common/src/site/markdown/release/0.13.1/RELEASENOTES.0.13.1.md
	deleted:    hadoop-common-project/hadoop-common/src/site/markdown/release/0.20.204.1/CHANGES.0.20.204.1.md
	deleted:    hadoop-common-project/hadoop-common/src/site/markdown/release/0.20.204.1/RELEASENOTES.0.20.204.1.md
{noformat}

* Similarly, docs were generated for some unreleased versions:

{noformat}
	hadoop-common-project/hadoop-common/src/site/markdown/release/2.6.5/
	hadoop-common-project/hadoop-common/src/site/markdown/release/2.6.6/
	hadoop-common-project/hadoop-common/src/site/markdown/release/2.7.3/
	hadoop-common-project/hadoop-common/src/site/markdown/release/2.7.4/
	hadoop-common-project/hadoop-common/src/site/markdown/release/2.8.1/
	hadoop-common-project/hadoop-common/src/site/markdown/release/2.8.2/
	hadoop-common-project/hadoop-common/src/site/markdown/release/2.9.0/
{noformat}

* I better understand your desire to close JIRAs now, since I'm worried about adding/dropping JIRAs when regenerating the release notes. Can you comment on any quick parity checks, e.g. seeing if the # of JIRAs has changed? Our fix versions are still not being reliably set, I ran [this query|https://issues.apache.org/jira/issues/?jql=project%20in%20(HADOOP%2C%20HDFS%2C%20YARN%2C%20MAPREDUCE)%20and%20fixVersion%20%3D%20%222.8.1%22%20and%20fixVersion%20!%3D%20%222.9.0%22] and it shows 44 JIRAs that are fixVersion 2.8.1 and 2.8.2 but not 2.9.0 (almost certainly errors).

bq. Looks like some releases were deleted in this update:

Correct.  There were no JIRA issues assigned to those releases.  A bug fix to RDM means empty releases no longer generate data.

bq. docs were generated for some unreleased versions

Correct.  If there is an unreleased version that has issues assigned to it, it will still get content created.  RDM has always had this behavior and it mimics how Hadoop's CHANGES.TXT file worked.  I think the last time I generated the base data set I manually deleted releases that were under active development.  But there was only one or two.  Now that we have like 5 of them, it seems rather pointless.
Change this to be a blocker, since it needs to go in before -beta1.
Ping, should we just get this in?

I'm really confused as to why the toc macro would suddenly start failing, especially when other toc macros are fine.

@#$%^@#$%#$

The problem is the angle brackets in the http lines.  The toc blows up because the rest of the document blows up.  Thanks for the helpful error message.

* change the markdown files that were blowing up with http://<foo> to http://foo
